channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2015 The New York Times Company

item.title: Video of ‘El Chapo’ Prison Break in Mexico Surfaces
item.description: Surveillance footage shows the moment the drug lord broke out of a Mexican prison.
item.dc:creator: AZAM AHMED and KATIE ROGERS

item.title: I.M.F.’s Insistence on Greek Debt Relief Adds to Complexity of Talks
item.description: The fund’s decision to go public with its concerns made clear that a draft agreement was only a starting point for further discussions.
item.dc:creator: JAMES KANTER and JACK EWING
item.media:description: The Greek finance minister, Euclid Tsakalotos, in a Parliament session Wednesday before lawmakers considered elements of the new bailout deal.

item.title: Macedonia’s Prime Minister to Resign, Paving Way for April Elections
item.description: As part of an agreement with opposition parties, the premier, Nikola Gruevski, who is reeling from a wiretapping scandal, will resign by Jan.15.
item.dc:creator: ALEKSANDAR DIMISHKOVSKI and RICK LYMAN
item.media:description: Prime Minister Nikola Gruevski of Macedonia addressed the media after 13 hours of negotiations with opposition party leaders in Skopje on Wednesday.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Google Maps Changes Name on Disputed South China Sea Shoal
item.description: Complaints were raised after the Internet giant dropped Scarborough Shoal, a longstanding name taken from a ship that smashed against it in 1784, and described the island as part of China’s Zhongsha chain.
item.dc:creator: AUSTIN RAMZY
item.media:description: A Filipino businessman, Mel Velarde, pointing to a replica of a 1734 map he bought at auction in London that shows Scarborough Shoal as part of Philippine territory under Spanish rule. The Philippine government requested copies of historical maps for its arbitration case against China in The Hague.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: A Gap Lingers in Taiwan’s Wartime Memory
item.description: Some say a 1945 air raid on Taipei by American bombers has been ignored by the government, with no official events to mark its anniversary and no physical memorial for the dead.
item.dc:creator: AUSTIN RAMZY
item.media:description: The Japanese Governor-General's Office, now the Presidential Office Building, suffered heavy damage in the May 31, 1945, bombing raid.

item.title: China Says Detained Tourists Were Watching Terrorist Propaganda
item.description: Nine foreigners from South Africa, Britain and India, part of a group of 20 travelers, have been jailed since Friday.
item.dc:creator: ANDREW JACOBS

item.title: Yemen’s Houthis Lose Aden Airport in New Fighting
item.description: The seizure of the airport by southern fighters was the Houthis’ biggest setback since they stormed Aden more than three months ago.
item.dc:creator: SAEED AL-BATATI and KAREEM FAHIM
item.media:description: Anti-Houthi militia members on Tuesday at the entrance to Aden's international airport, which they had recaptured from Shiite Houthi rebels.

item.title: Oskar Gröning, Ex-SS Soldier at Auschwitz, Gets Four-Year Sentence
item.description: The former soldier, 94, was found guilty of complicity in the murder of 300,000 Hungarian Jews brought to the Nazi death camp in 1944.
item.dc:creator: ALISON SMALE
item.media:description: Oskar Gröning was charged with complicity in the murder of 300,000 Hungarian Jews and was sentenced on Wednesday to four years in prison.

item.title: News Analysis: Obama’s Iran Nuclear Deal Pits His Faith in Diplomacy Against Skepticism
item.description: The Tehran accord represents a larger conflict of visions as critics question the wisdom of negotiating with what they see as an adversary that cannot be trusted.
item.dc:creator: PETER BAKER

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: How Obama Should Sell the Iran Deal
item.description: The Iran accord is not a Nixon-in-China watershed. But it’s an effective arms control agreement that deserves support.
item.category: Arms Control and Limitation and Disarmament
item.dc:creator: JAMES P. RUBIN
item.media:description: President Obama and Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. just before the announcement of the Iran deal.

item.title: Shanghai Disney Plans Unveiled: Big on ‘Pirates,’ but No Space Mountain
item.description: The company’s resort, its first in mainland China, represents a major bet on westernized leisure travel and an effort to stoke sales of Disney products.
item.dc:creator: DAVID BARBOZA and BROOKS BARNES
item.media:description: Robert A. Iger, Disney’s chief executive and chairman, with a scale model of the future Shanghai Disney Resort. Its centerpiece castle is billed as the “tallest, largest and most interactive” of any at a Disney park.

item.title: Contributing Op-Ed Writer: Overregulating Life in Greece
item.description: It’s not a matter of austerity versus stimulus. The country needs structural reforms.
item.dc:creator: STEVEN RATTNER

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: Germany’s Destructive Anger
item.description: If it is going to lead Europe, it can’t act as if it’s simply a victim.
item.dc:creator: JACOB SOLL

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: ‘Cinema on the Edge’ to Take Chinese Movies to New York
item.description: After the authorities effectively shut down the Beijing Independent Film Festival last year, a team decided to take a selection of Chinese movies to New York. The films will be screened from Aug. 7 to Sept. 13, featuring works by Ai Weiwei, Hu Jie, Li Luo, Zou Xueping and Yang Mingming.
item.dc:creator: AMY QIN
item.media:credit: Courtesy of the Beijing Independent Film Festival
item.media:description: Ai Weiwei’s “Ping’an Yueqing” (2011), a documentary examining the death of an activist who stood up for his fellow villagers in a land dispute with local officials, will be shown in New York at “Cinema on the Edge: The Best of the Beijing Independent Film Festival 2012-2014.”

item.title: I.M.F. Demands Greece Debt Relief as Condition for Bailout
item.description: The International Monetary Fund said in an analysis submitted to Greece’s creditors that the country’s debt load was unsustainable.
item.dc:creator: JACK EWING
item.media:description: Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras of Greece, left, with President François Hollande of France, center, and Prime Minister Charles Michel of Belgium at the start of the eurozone leaders' summit on the Greek crisis at the European Council headquarters in Brussels.

item.title: Micron Technology Is Said to Be Takeover Target of Chinese Company
item.description: Tsinghua Unigroup, China’s top microchip maker, is preparing a plan to bid $23 billion for the American company, a person briefed on the matter said.
item.dc:creator: PAUL MOZUR and QUENTIN HARDY
item.media:description: The memory chips made by the Micron, which is based in Idaho, sit in data centers and servers that process the flow of information across the globe.

item.title: World Briefing: Ukraine: Blasts Target Police Stations
item.description: Two policemen were hurt Tuesday in explosions at two police stations in the western Ukrainian city of Lviv.
item.dc:creator: REUTERS

item.title: Russia Quickly Maneuvers to Capitalize on Iran Nuclear Deal
item.description: Minutes after the accord was clinched, the Russian foreign minister went on television to emphasize the benefits that it could hold for Russia.
item.dc:creator: DAVID M. HERSZENHORN
item.media:description: Sergey V. Lavrov, center, the Russian foreign minister, with Frank-Walter Steinmeier, the German foreign minister, left, and Secretary of State John Kerry before a session Tuesday in Vienna.

item.title: World Briefing: Kuwait: 29 to Be Tried in Mosque Attack
item.description: Defendants included Kuwaitis, Saudis, Pakistanis, a fugitive of uncertain nationality and “illegal residents.”
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: Thailand: 10 Jailed in Lèse-Majesté Case
item.description: A Thai military court sentenced 10 people for distributing online content that it said insulted the monarchy.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS
